course.subject: COMP
course.name: Object-Oriented Programming and Data Structures
course.description: To learn the fundamental concepts and techniques behind object-oriented programming. They include: abstract data types; creation, initialization, and destruction of objects; class hierarchies; polymorphism, inheritance and dynamic binding; generic programming using templates. To learn the object-oriented view of data structures: linked lists, stacks, queues, binary trees, and algorithms such as searching and hashing.

reviews.author: xdlok
reviews.title: y u do dis, long?
reviews.comment_content:
This course looks deeper into the world of OOP and introduces some more data structures.

Contents that will be tested (Not completely in order):
OOP:
Class constructors, destructors, Order of construction/destruction
Operator Overloading
Abstract Data Type
Static member
Generic Programming
Inheritance (public, protected, private)
Polymorphism: Overriding, virtual, ABC
Data Structures:
Stacks and Queues (again)
BST
AVL trees
Hash tables

Contents that are not tested (Only taught in Professor Quan's session):
Basic algorithm analysis (big O)
Insertion sort, Merge sort
Counting sort, Radix sort (As application of Queues)
Heap, Heap sort, Priority Queues

The stuff not tested here are basically 3711/H stuff.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ah the teaching. As I always said: 厲害了，我的龍.

I have attended all his lectures except for one. And I would say that, his teaching is actually not that bad. His accent is ... Interesting, but I have no problem understanding. He sometimes give us the motivation behind something, like for operator overloading, we want the operation to be closed (return value be the same type), and he goes off to say something about group, rings and fields, etc. Definitely not useful for exam, but interesting.

Speaking about usefulness in exam, oh my god there is not much. Often he goes over the important topics so fast that you couldn't see his taillight. Inheritance is done in ONE lecture. You read that right, ONE, as in less than two, so that there is more time for him to talk about the extra stuff. The thing is, he will go on to say that something is not important, but then that something appeared in the exam! I guess you can see that the exam papers are prepared mostly by Desmond, and not Long. For example, he said that private and protected inheritance is not important, so he didn't go over it. Then in the exam, it appeared. Surprise! Long said that he looked over the paper to make sure that only the content taught by both lecturers will appear on the exam, but the word 'TAUGHT' is used very loosely, as some topics are technically 'taught', but even as a person who attended almost all of his lectures, I don't remember it (E.g.: const-ness). When I asked him, he said: It was in one of the page in my slides! 厲害了，我的龍. He often talked about the concept, and rarely the code, which is basically what the whole exam is about.

By the way, around midterm, only 20 people are present. Near the finals, 5. 5/around 90 people attended his lectures. I guess the rest watched or attended Desmond's lectures (the smart choice). Keep in mind though, this is a 9am lecture. But I couldn't help but imagining the face of him when he invigilate the final exam (for the students from his lecture) and saw that holy shit, there were 90 people registered in his session.

What I would suggest is, to just go with Desmond's lecture or videos. If you are really stubborn like me and stuck with Long's lectures, do the past papers. It will save your ass in the midterm and final. It was only when I was attempting the past papers do I realize how screwed I am, and how 厲害 my 龍 is.

I guess one of the problems of this course is that, questions in exam are often stuff that Desmond have mentioned in his lecture, but not in Professor Quan's.

The labs could be time-consuming, so at least read the site before coming. Not much to say.
reviews.comment_grading:
Remark: try to take this course in fall to avoid the CS guys!
Check other people's review for the scheme.
I got below mean in PA1, >=1sd for PA2 and 3, full marks in lab, 8x in midterm, 89 in finals and got A. Although my friend, with only 1 or 2 points higher than me in midterm and final and almost the same everything else, got A+. It leaves you to judge the grading.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fine. The labs don't take too long to finish; the PA takes more time to debug, but still manageable.

reviews.author: rind
reviews.title: Very good Instructor
reviews.comment_content:
Continuation of COMP2011
1. Intro, review, const-ness, lambda
A brief review of what have been learnt from 2011, introduction to lambda expression.

2. Constructors and Destructor
OOP concept. It is very important to distinguish different kinds of constructors and their use-cases. Like: why a conversion constructor only take one parameter? Ans: for implicit conversion when we are doing something like: Word a = "abcd"
This topic plays an important role in the next topic when discussing Inheritance (like order of constructions), do remember to do more practice and understand each constructor thoroughly

3. Inheritance and Polymorphism
OOP concept again.

4. Generic Programming
The power of template for code re-using. Do pay attention to the syntax.
Operator overloading is a very important part of this course. Make sure you know how to write the function declaration of each operator (like << , [ ] requires two function signature...)

5. STL
Application Programming Interface (API) for extremely useful data structure (vector, stack, queue, map...) You don't have to memorize all the things, but better get more practice.

6. Hashing
More theoretical. Something you will see again in COMP3711. Very basic and there is basically no Math behind this chapter. (They just teach you the method)

7. Binary Search Tree
Another data-structure.

8. Rvalue reference and Move Semantics
Better use of resource: temporary objects, move constructor, move assignment operator
reviews.comment_teaching:
It is the first time Cecia teaches this course. Probably because Desmond won't teach 2012 next year.

Since my COMP2011 was taught by Cecia, I get used to her pace and style. I would say Cecia is a great instructor in this course also (Besides Desmond :D).

I don't know how do people learn programming, but for me it starts from the basic: make sure you understand every line of code, what is the meaning/usage of such design, what if I change something, will the program still works? (You have to be "naughty" and use your imagination to change the codes and give an explanation of the new result. 中文講就係舉一反三)

Therefore, Cecia should be the one you look for if you want your basics to be stronger. Usually she will give a more simpler example compared to the lecture note when starting a new topic. And there will be some "tricky" polling questions that allows you to understand more about the mechanism.

Since it is her first year teaching COMP2012, her pace is a little bit slower than expected. Resulting in rushing the last few topics, but I think it is still ok to handle given you have solid understanding in all the topics before.

I don't have any experiences on programming besides the intro course. But from COMP2011 to 2012, two A+s, the only thing I can do now is a big appreciation on her ;)

reviews.comment_workload:
The workload of this course mainly comes from PA and lab that requires you to catch up with course material.
PA1, 3 are easier but PA 2 and 4 are much difficult. Especially PA 4 costs me around 2-3 days to finish.

The labs are quite boring. In Comp2011 we usually have some logic demanding labs that requires like 2-3 hours to finish. However the lab this semester is too easy. Maybe you change 2-3 lines of code, or copying other functions to finish the tasks. Usually it takes 15-60mins for each lab. Sometimes you don't have to understand anything new to finish the lab.

The way I learn 2011/2012 is develop reasonable explanations for all the phenomenon. (Not applicable for everyone, just if you are interested.)
E.g. It is very hard to memorize the order of construction/destruction
Then you can think of building a house. You have to gather all the components before you can really have a house. If your house requires a component from other class (own other class object), then ask someone to build the component for you (class constructor); If your house is base on another house (inherited), then ask other to build the base for you first (base class constructor), then you can stack the components one by one and finally create a house.

By some "stories" or "analogy", try to come up with a reasonable mechanism for all the things in this course. Just like building a house, your base determines how tall you can build.

reviews.author: Chino
reviews.title: Great instructor
reviews.comment_content:
Basically follow the stream from COMP 2011.
the course focuses more on the OOP part features of C++.
Mainly include:
1. Order of constructor and destructor
2. inheritance and abstract class
3. generic programming and template

It also includes some basic concept of algorithm and data structure:
1. Binary search tree and AVL (AVL part self learn, not examined)
2. hash table

Some small yet important feature of C++ is also included but in a smaller fraction
1. constness of variable
2. lambda function
3. STL library
4. static keyword (self learn, not examined)
5. namespace (self learn, not examined)

Overall well structured, easy to manage if you takes time to read through the lecture note and play around all the features.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very well teaching, teach in a moderate pace and allows you to think and ask questions after each short sections and after lectures.

Explain in detail of every piece of code in the example clearly and points out all the important points that should be handled carefully.

p.s. his tone is easy to follow, don't be scared by his name lol.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite competitive.

lab + assignment: 8% + 40%
midterm: 12%
final: 40%

The midterm is tricky and final will be easier (at least for my year and past paper I did). Final is more important if you aim high grade.

try to aim at 90+% for A+, 80/85% for A.

the score is highly deviated, so scoring a mean might just be around B-/C+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Lab is very easy if you pay attention on the lesson, basically just focus on one features taught previously, follow the instruction and attend the lab on time then you can get the marks.

Assignment is a bit challenging, try to understand every parts of the given skeleton code before go directly into the tasks. Do it at least a week before the deadline and leave enough time for you to debug, piazza is a good place for you to find some of your potential bug.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Why is Desmond the best instructor that I have ever learned from in HKUST?

In terms of technical efforts, It’s clear he has tried to make the tragic idea of sitting through or watching lectures as smooth as possible. Crisp and clear sounding mic? Done. Punctual lecture recording uploads? Done. Lecture recordings with mic connected to the audio? Done. Lecture recordings all compiled in a website? Done. Lecture recordings all compiled in a website plus progress of lecture slides (e.g. topic XYZ p.23-48) next to each video? Done. What more can I ask for? I have not once waited for him to upload his lecture videos if I missed class. And for revision, if I forgot some topic, I didn’t have to spend an hour opening fifteen tabs of zoom recordings to figure out which video it was.

Desmond is unparalleled, compared to most instructors. The others simply don’t pay attention to minute details like this that make it easier for students to consume their knowledge.

His teaching is also powerful. Each sentence he speaks is so dynamic and meaningful; he could literally become a voice actor. There are some professors who speak like a robot for half the lecture to explain a topic, and then suddenly express a slight hint of their quasi-personality to show that the topic they’ve taught is indeed, remarkable or interesting. Desmond doesn’t speak like a robot at all. He teaches with the curiosity of students in mind and in a way, he is sort of performing when he does so.

Aside from his oral delivery, his ideas are very intuitive. He is not reading lecture notes most of the time but instead giving these very simplified and dumbed-down programs. Surprisingly, his programs cover most of the lecture notes. He has consistently (and jokingly) thrown shade on some of Professor Mak’s complicated example programs that reside in the lecture notes, which I live for.

When Desmond teaches, he has shown immense empathy to the students. For one, I think he knows that people lose focus normally. Every time I lost focus in class, Desmond would literally repeat his latest sentence, word for word, as if he could sense that I was zoning out to another dimension. On a serious note, I think if I had some attention deficit, this class wouldn’t be that bad. This obviously may have increased the time of the lectures but I don’t think Desmond cares. I mean, it is clear that he isn’t there because he is a professor and needs to finish the syllabus before the end of the semester because it is his job. He is there because he wants to teach. Desmond also knows that students struggle and acknowledged the difficulty of the course on multiple occasions. He has made it so clear that help is found whenever needed and this made it much easier to complete this course.  

Desmond also has a website where you can see his weekly schedule. If you can’t make it to his office hours, and you missed TA’s office hours, you can email him to perhaps book an appointment and your name will be on the schedule. Like what? This guy is just so detailed.

Overall, I think Desmond is an excellent teacher and he knows that. I hope he never stops teaching.

reviews.author: SARSalad
reviews.title: Unpredecented online lecture and assessment experience!
reviews.comment_content:
(The midterm wasn't conducted in this sem due to online teaching mode, so this is my assumption of the topics covered before and after the midterm in normal teaching schedule)   
Before mid-term:
0. Revision of COMP 2011 (const-ness, dynamic array, linked list & C++ Class Basic): since this course is the continuation of COMP 2011, lecturers will review on the topics covered after the mid-term of COMP 2011 to ensure everyone is ready for what is coming.  

1. Constructor & Destructor: You have seen them for the first time in COMP 2011, but they actually take several forms. You are going to understand how these forms of Ctor and Dtor mix up in the object construction and destruction.

2. Inheritance and Polymorphism: The lecturers from now on will groan about code re-use and introduce these two major OOP topic in order to clear way such frustration, they are also reflected in reality too!

3. Generic Programming: I have mentioned the hatred of the lecturers against code re-use. With templates, we have virtually no other means of duplicating similar-looking codes. If you don't think certain operators (+,-, +=, <<) work well for user-defined data types, you can even re-define them by operator overloading.

After mid-term:
4. Hashing: the mechanism behind searching. Without coding, this is the easiest data structure to learn.

5. Binary search tree (BST): The pain of recursion curses my body once more when implementing this data structure. You are also going to learn the three ways of traversing the tree, it's great that it couldn't be directly examined in the online exam!

6. AVL: Just BST plus balancing, so make sure you understand BST beforehand.

7. rvalue Reference and Move Semantics: the story of temporary objects attempting to extend their lifespan with rvalue reference but end up being abused by move semantic. This final topic can possibly "move" down your grades if being taken lightly of, be cautious!
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lab session on the first three weeks and the last week were used for revision of COMP 2011 and teaching move semantic, which is brilliantly planned in my opinion as they are crucial for us, they act as the building block and the finisher to 2012 respectively.

Dr. Mak elaborates concept very clearly and is willing to answer students' questions in-class and post-class, especially with the teaching mode. I feel pity for the one leaving right at the end of class and missing precious learning time. The interaction between students with lecturers bucked the trend. I wish we can maintain the same learning vibe However, he is very strict in terms of quizzes and teaches very fast (only held one make-up class). If you are a proficient programmer, go for Dr. Mak's class.



OTHERWISE, GO FOR DESMOND AT ANY COST! WORTHY AND YOU WILL GAIN MORE THAN ADEQUATE!

reviews.author: C.C
reviews.title: excellent data structure + programming course
reviews.comment_content:
Asides from teaching you many useful C++ features, I think a big focus is on language concepts and how to explain various C++ standards e.g. why shouldn’t you declare a pure virtual destructor without implementation in a class hierarchy?, why can’t you use a rvalue reference to initialize another rvalue reference ? etc.

Of cause as the course title suggests, they will also teach you some useful data Structures like BST & hash table and you will have plenty opportunities to practice applying those data structures in PA and labs.

You’ll find out in other courses many more application of those data structures like hash table can be used to improve run time of sorting. Overall the content is very important and interesting.

Exams are quite competitive, in addition to assessing your mastery on course material and problem solving skills, they also test your stamina ie. Can you code for long hour even when you’re tired? exam is ~3 hrs you know.

Also in exam time allocation is key, I got low mark in final because I spent too much time challenging the hard question and rushing through easy questions, this resulted in tons of careless mistakes. So allocate your time more rationally.

Speaking of the final exam, in the last question (AVL), If you have very good concept of pointers (COMP2011 topic) I think you can solve the problem without using any AVL technique which is out syllabus. So make sure you do through review on pointer and how they may be creatively used.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very good teaching from Desmond, he explained complicated topics in a way you can understand e.g. when he taught move semantics, instead of following the slide he gave us the big picture (resource stealing) first, he also illustrated using actual examples.

Also his passion in teaching is highly contagious, you'll suddenly be very motivated too when you attend his lecture lol

TA team is also very good, especially Dinh Anh Dung (the lead TA i guess) he answer questions on Piazza very fast and concise. I also like the 2 PAs he designed which is PA2 tournament matching and PA3 tic tac toe with minimax, at least for me they're really fun.

In PA3, interestingly the TA made an important logical mistake in the hash table optimization for alpha-beta pruning that made the algorithm incorrect,  however the mistake is ... super tricky and technical, so (unsurprisingly) no one (a whole class of few hundred people!) found out until the TA later found out himself lol. But that error is really just an exception, they don't make mistake 99% of the time. Still when you're doing assignment, you should think more critically and actually understand the purpose of the code and the logic behind it. I too thought I'd throughly understood the code, but I still couldn't spot that huge mistake, so I actually didn't throughly understand the code ... lol

There're around 700 questions on Piazza and only 13 unanswered. So the teaching team did a great job.
reviews.comment_grading:
PA and lab almost full mark

midterm exam: ~83% (~+1.6 sd)
final exam: ~76% (~+1.5 sd)
overall ~86%

grade: A+

thanks for the leniency!
reviews.comment_workload:
5 mins lab attendance each week and  3 PAs. On average, you can finish labs within 1 hour PA within a day, but I always spent additional time to triple check and make sure there's no mistake.

Also do more past papers to train intuition on exam questions, this's key to answer questions very fast in exam. Note that intuition != logical thinking and there're good videos on Youtube explaining how to take advantage intuition in competitive exams. But over reliance on intuition may backfire as it's error prone.

reviews.author: operator=
reviews.title: Desmond is a god
reviews.comment_content:
The content mainly covers deeper learning in OOP.
First some reviews about pointers, const and lambda
Next new things about OOP

3.Generic programming

reviews.comment_teaching: Desmond focuses on the logic of each piece of knowledge(in his word, xxx is sth beautiful) and likes to repeat some important points(sometimes in English, Putonghua and Cantonese) and demo important procedures like ("Can we go into the body now? No, we have to first initialize all its data member!",  bst node delete bst tree, node, tree, node,tree....) This teaching style really facilitates my understanding of new stuff. Honestly speaking, although the content in comp2012 is a bit less harder than the pointer part in 2011 when you first learn it, the overall difficulties is much harder than 2011. Although some students with good foundations and talent may find that the speed a little bit low, I first think that if desmond spent less time in saying sth like " do you want to learn sth new please say yes!", we can speed up our teaching progress and there will be no addition class( I don't really hate addition class but when it is conducted on Fri evening or the day when you have a whole day class it really breaks your mood.), when the difficulties of the content is increasing, it acts as a buffer for you to recall and catch up. The power of brainwashing is so strong and I believe everyone who takes his class will remember some typical lines.Another feature of his class is that he encourages us to response and ask questions in class and it is really beneficial to learn from classmates' questions. Maybe for some students they don't like this kind of hyperbole, but for students who get below mean in 1021 this teaching style really enables us to have a better understanding of new content and builds a good foundation.
reviews.comment_grading:
Unlike comp2011 where they require you to think of some algorithms like merge sort, or how to locate the parent of a tree in a short period of time under the condition that you know nothing about algorithm and are unfamiliar with the data structure such as linked list, both midterm and final in comp2012 requires you a full understanding of the content desmond teaches in class and you may find that the exam is much more doable.  
I guess the grading is not bad because I think desmond is a good guy.
Lab(10%):  full  
Assignment(30%) : -0.024, nearly full
midterm(20%):  mean:63.5, sd:16.5   median: 64  me: 88
final(40%):     mean:63.78 sd: 16.9      median: 65 me: 92
(the mean and sd is before appealing because an answer
of T/F is incorrect and they regrade Q2 so I think the mean would be slightly higher.)
grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is nearly the same as comp2011(may be slightly heavier because of pa2)
The labs are easier than 2011.
For pa1, it requires us to think of some algorithms which means the difficulties don't lie in how to write a constructor...
For pa2, whether you know where to add a virtual keyword or add public inheritance does no help to the solution. We have to read a lot of .h files to guess what the game rules and how to implement it. Although I know that the intention is good because it is what real life does and I do revere the hard work of the designer who spends a month to design this game, there are still some bugs and umm the clue is a little less and in Chinese, it is sth like 对牛弹琴 because the designer thinks we can understand him but it is obvious that we haven't reached that stage, and finally, this homework turns into a task filling assignment with clear instruction and it loses all its meanings and this assignment becomes totally a failure.
For pa3, it is just some basic training of BST and template so it is much easier than the first two assignments and it is really nice when there are lots of ddl approaching final.
For exams I do recommend doing past papers because desmond likes to follow the style of the past.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Simply excellent, Desmond is the best instructor you can possibly hope to get in a programming course, he gives many examples and constantly asks questions to make sure you understand what he is saying, and even repeats in 3 different languages just so he can explain his ideas more clearly.

He also sends a lot of emails out to further explain the concepts. One of the most enthusiastic lecturers I have ever seen in UST.

Lab sessions are conducted orderly and swiftly, the TAs do a good job.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 Programming assignments (10% each): 3 assignments, each about a different area, (for this semester: class, inheritance and BST), difficulty is acceptable other than assignment 2 where the TA made the assignment far too complex and had to spend about a week reworking the assignment to make it easier.

Laboratory exercises (10%): 1 lab per week, finish the code and attend the session, you may be asked a question by the TAs regarding the lab, the questions are mostly easy and TAs are lenient with the score, not difficult to get full marks here.

Midterm (20%): True or False questions and short answers, mostly about constructors and destructors. Doing the past papers here is key.

Final examination (40%): Same as the midterm, covers the entire course equally, again doing the past papers is key.

I got slightly above mean in the midterm, mean in finals, attended all labs and got around 95% in all 3 assignments, ended up with a B, decent grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
OK for a 4 credit course.

Labs do not take very long to complete and is not too difficult, often its just completing a simple class definition.

Assignments are also manageable, however time needs to be spent debugging and making sure you are ready for all of the test cases. In my opinion, 2012 has easier assignments than 2011, since what you need to do is more clear in this course.

Exams require you to be very clear on the concepts related to the course, and doing the past papers is extremely important since the questions in the exam are closely related down to the way they are asked. However some questions rely on your programming skills, and no amount of studying and doing past papers can help there.

reviews.author: anonymousSheep
reviews.title: Professor was actually good
reviews.comment_content:
Content is structured around the ++ aspect of C++. Unlike COMP2011 where most of the teaching revolves around teaching students the basics of programming, COMP2012 starts getting down into the nitty gritty features and workings of C++.

Starting this year, the course curriculum switched from C++98 to C++11. Think about that.... That's 11 years of development experience that programmers used to improve the language. So, you'll get all the fun features that supposedly make life a little easier than when compared to the old revisions of C++/

You will learn the following:

- Pointers! (Absolutely crucial. If you're unfamiliar with pointers. better be ready before the semester starts)
- Classes and Objects (70% of the course revolves around classes and the properties of classes)
- Templates
- Abstract Data Structures (Linked Lists, Binary Trees, Etc)

Mostly a continuation of COMP2011. But rather than teaching you how to use the tools of C++, you'll be learning how to use the tools to create something, like creating a bootleg version of UNO! in the console (Really! It was the second assignment.)

I personally liked the course, but it might be a little challenging for some especially if you're weak in pointers and recursion. It's an integral part in this course. If you can't handle it, you can consider dropping the course. But that also generally means dropping your major since I don't think anyone does this course for fun. So don't drop the course and just suck it up.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Brian was an excellent teacher. He was always punctual and well prepared for his lectures. He spoke well with clear diction and with an easy to understand accent. He makes frequent use of diagrams overlayed on notes to illustrate examples and content. There are also many places where students get the opportunity to answer questions that promotes learning. It was a shame that I didn't really start paying attention until near the end of the semester. I would 10/10 recommend taking this course with Brian.

The TAs were also generally helpful in the labs and would patiently assist us in debugging our programs when stuck. I would say that this course easily has one of the better teaching staff.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading can be a little strict sometimes, especially with regards to the assignments. You can't really know what to expect sometimes. Many times, the assignments will give you 10 test cases that you'll work so hard to get right. But then you get over confident about how your program will perform under scrutiny designed to make your program fail. Mid-term exam was also hard as you'd really really have to understand it well in order to debug other people's mistakes.( One of the questions was to spot errors in code ).

Grading distribution is as follows:

1. Assignments 1, 2, 3 (6%, 9%, 9%)
2. Lab Exercises and Attendance (10%)
3. Mid-term Exam (26%)
4. Final Exam (40%)
reviews.comment_workload:
As with any programming course and even language courses. You can't learn the language just by reading the lecture notes of cramming just before the exam. You have to use it, write it and even dream of it in order to do well on the exams. Therefore, you'll have to spend time every week working on the lab exercises and upcoming assignments. On average, each assignment takes around 6-9 hours of work depending on your experience and effort. Sometimes more if you really want to score well. You'll also spend lots of time tinkering with the Eclipse IDE as it really freaking sucks. I never EVER got it to work properly on my computer at home, so I had to work on the assignments at school. Because if it don't compile on their machines, you be damned.

Also, pro tip, install Linux, install Valgrind, and install eclipse or any IDE of your liking (I personally use CLion since it's not dumb like eclipse), that way you can check for memory leaks before you submit your assignment.

fair grading. Neither very good nor bad.

reviews.comment_workload: The workload is a little bit heavy as like comp2011, every week has a lab, and the assignments are quite time-consuming.

reviews.author: amyriad
reviews.title: Victim of Online Learning
reviews.comment_content:
Refer to other reviews for details.

(Basically STL and OOP concepts)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Desmond's teaching is Interesting.

Also, he may guide you through many common mistakes that might appear in the exam.

He may explain important concepts in different languages (English, Cantonese, Mandarin(, and learning Korean(?)))
reviews.comment_grading:
Originally there are mid-term exam and final exam.

Due to the sudden change to online learning, the final exam is removed, and the score distribution is changed to an extra assignment and more weighting of previous stuffs. That's what the nightmare happens (specifically for this semester):

The midterm exam was not giving enough time for students to finish in normal writing speed. (If you think you have finished half of the pages in 45% of time. you are not suppose to finish it on time before the exam ends), so most students complained that the exam cannot even be finished, this caused the grade less dependent on the course expected outcomes, but rather whether you realised that you need to write extremely fast from the start of the exam. Everything sucked. Many students had reflected this situation to Desmond, and he promised to set the questions better in the final exam. However, fate gave no chance for everyone. There was no exam, meaning no hope for rescue, since basically people can get close to full marks in homeworks and labs, so it became the so-called 一試定生死 (a single exam deciding your fate) and the worse is that this was unexpected. That made you suddenly lose all your passion into the course since you knew it is of no return, and your grade was going to be rotten. You knew this is destiny, and you knew this is unfortune. That's all.
reviews.comment_workload:
Need to submit programming assignments using the recently taught structures, also there are labs every week.

The lab may be late at night, but once you demonstrate the working result to the TAs, you can leave immediately. (So better choose the seat closest to the TAs to get reviewed earlier)

reviews.author: ptrknow
reviews.comment_content:
If COMP2011 focuses on programming logic, then COMP2012 focuses on the syntactic issues and the behind-the-scenes operations related to OOP. Basic data structures (mainly about binary trees) are also introduced, in the perspective of OOP.

I myself do better on programming logic, so I like the data structure part of this course much more than the OOP part. (This in turns means I like 2011 more than 2012.)

But of course, the contents are fruitful.

P.S. Be sure you don't forget pointers and recursions...
reviews.comment_grading:
3 PAs 24% (6 + 9 + 9%)
9 Labs 10%
Quiz 5%
Midterm 25%
Final 36%

PA2 and PA3 have tricky parts. Better spend more time thinking about (and improving on) your solution so that you would have fewer problems on the actual test cases.

Labs are generally easy. One of the labs (which is about STL vector) can be quite challenging.

Quiz is conducted in early February, consisting of 19 MCQs testing on pointers, reference and constness. Some of them are really tricky.

Midterm and Final are not very difficult, but the mark distribution is quite concentrated around the mean. In this semester there is no T/F question (maybe because of the existence of quiz). I suggest you pay more attention to inheritance and operator overloading.

Statistics:
Quiz: Mean 13/19, SD 2.5
Midterm: Mean 56/100, SD 18.3
Final: Mean 69/100, SD 15.2

My result:
PA: 23.64/24 (fail one test case each in PA2 and PA3)
Lab: 10/10
Quiz: 13/19 (mean)
Midterm: 77/100 (+1.1 SD)
Final: 84.5/100 (+1 SD)
Grade: A (Overall: ~86/100)

Leave you to judge the grading.

reviews.author: yusless
reviews.title: Overall a good course
reviews.comment_content: The prerequisite for this course is COMP2011. It expands upon COMP2011 as you delve deeper in the world of OOP and data structures.
reviews.comment_teaching: Desmond is an amazing lecturer. He really goes in-depth with his lectures, making sure to give numerous examples to really make his point. It is a joy to be taught under him, as he explains in a clear and easy-to-understand manner, and he exudes lots of passion for teaching. Best lecturer I've had for COMP courses so far.
reviews.comment_grading:
It is really strict in my opinion, as the assignments are given to you beforehand with some test cases, usually 10 of them. In general, these test cases are the bare minimum you need to obtain a passing grade as your program can run. However, your assignment will be marked on more than 10 test cases, making debugging your code and avoiding memory leaks an utmost importance in order to obtain a good grade in the assignments.

Labs were more lenient, as the lab assistants usually just look at the console output of your program. However, you may be asked some questions regarding your code or some potential problems if something is added/removed, etc. For those labs, you'll need to complete both the lab program and answer the question for the full mark for the lab part.

Mid-term was quite early, so we had to make sure your logic is perfect and you understand the chapters well. Even though there wasn't a lot of content in terms of chapters taught, the depth of the midterms should not be underestimated. Make sure to study hard, preferably as much as possible for the exams and midterms.

Grading distribution is as follows:

1. Assignments 1, 2, 3 (6%, 9%, 9%)
2. Lab Exercises and Attendance (10%)
3. Mid-term Exam (26%)
4. Final Exam (40%)
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite heavy. There are labs for every week. In addition, the assignments need to be perfect in order to obtain a full mark. That means that the student has to spend lots of time debugging the code and make sure it's free of any memory leaks.

reviews.author: dearmrkris
reviews.comment_content:
这门课是Comp2011的延续，前半学期很多内容和2011重合，但是讲的比2011更深入、细致一些。这课难度没有想象中那么大，lab和三个大assignment写的程序都不算太复杂，skeleton code也给的挺详尽的，主要是训练学生如何完成一些大的program成为一名习惯良好的程序猿。不过作为学渣真的是不能相信cwiki上comp课的评价，oop的难度还是在那里的，workload不小，一个sem下来这门课投入的时间最多（当然还是烂龟了hhh）

我主要是来推荐instructor的，desmond真的是我见过的最好的cs老师，人特别nice很有耐心。教授上课很注重syntax细节， 重点的地方会重复两三遍，所以上课完全可以理解；课堂上很鼓励学生发言，每堂课都会脑洞大开测试各种syntax error；他自己还会抽休息时间给学生补课pointer/reference之类的，所有lecture都有录video，office hour之内之外都可以去找他，特别supportive &  reachable。大家也知道，在这种初阶编程课上，出bug的很多时候不是logic structure而是syntax，所以desmond的讲课方法我觉得还是挺科学的。

不知道是不是受instructor影响，这堂课的TA也是普遍非常helpful水平很高，会给一些指导，上lab的时候比2011好多了

reviews.comment_content: C++. If you are not going to become a software developer and can find a way to avoid the course, do it. So many better languages to learn with your time.

reviews.comment_grading:
All exams are in the classic braindead format of writing code by hand on paper with a pen. Having a hard time figuring out how that could be any dumber for a course that teaches programming.
Assignment grading is fair, though takes quite a while. We only received marking schemes for 1 of the 3 assignments beforehand.
Average is around C I think.
reviews.comment_workload:
Assignments are the usual computer science department "fill in the blanks", usually coupled with code we haven't been taught outside the blanks, which makes the assignments more annoying than anything else.
Midterm/finals are quite difficult.
Weekly labs require attendance and are easy, but do them before the session.

reviews.author: Rilakuma
reviews.comment_content: Although parts of the content in this course are closely related to COMP2011, the content is easier. But if you not, you can still work on the new part, like inheritance.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecture is quite boring. The lecture notes are also not clear, especially for the color tone of the notes. It makes the content unclear.
reviews.comment_grading: The lecturer gives some tips for us before the examination. The tips are VERY useful. The grading is much more related to the marks of assignments.
reviews.comment_workload:
1 mid-term exam 25%+1 final exam 40%+3 assignments 25%+lab marks 10%.
The assignments are quite difficult and complicated. As it gives a lot of guidelines and restrictions on developing codes, it restricts the creation of students. It will take almost a week to finish the assignment.
As usual, lab is necessary and 1 marks for attendance, 1 marks for completion of lab. Some labs are very difficult. You will need to finish the lab before going to the lab session.
It is quite normal that you need to spend time on the assignment and the lab task at the same period of time.

reviews.author: takecare
reviews.title: void* const CPPexcellentlecturer = Desmond; // :)
reviews.comment_content:
This term is a bit different from previous semesters in the order:
1.C++ class basics,
2.makefile and const-ness,
3.constructors & Destructor,
4.generic programming
(template, operator overloading, friend function),
5.Static Data and Methods
6.STL
(containers, iterators, and algorithms)
7.Namespace,
8. inheritance,
9. Abstract Data Types (doubly linked list),
10.Binary Search Trees
11. Hashing,
12. AVL trees

Desmond goes through all materials in detail, although not all materials are useful.
reviews.comment_teaching:
OMG It's Desmond!
He is very enthusiastic in teaching the course. People who used to understand VERY LITTLE about programming and computer knowledge can have a great improvement on completion of his teaching.

He is humorous and helpful in lessons. His additional materials (C++ FAQs, lecture videos, etc.) really are so handy for guys who do not read textbooks often like me. :P

The only slip is that he teaches at a slower speed and you are expected to join many makeup classes. Hence, 學霸 or people who love coding challenges are advised to take COMP2012H instead. (Actually I don't know why people getting A/A+ from prerequisite courses are not automatically branched into honour courses.)

Definitely not as hard as COMP2011. The assignments are not that difficult and the lab tasks are acceptable. To be honest, I think the course should focus more on OOP and data structures as equals since
1.C++ class basics,
2.makefile and const-ness,
3.constructors & Destructor,
are supposed to be taught in COMP2011 so that important concepts like multiple inheritance, balanced trees, B trees, union-find data structures should have been included.

P.S. Generally grading of COMP2011 will normally be stricter on Fall semesters and grading of COMP2012 will normally be stricter on Spring semesters, especially there are instructors other than Cecia, Desmond and Quan Long...so...plan your study path well. ;)

reviews.author: Alan Lai
reviews.title: Best Professor best course
reviews.comment_content:
Based on my understanding, the structure of CPP can categorize into more than six parts. Type, Function, Objects, Inheritance, Operator overloading, Template(STL), etc. Each abstracts the language features into a fundamental concept (not necessary) for all Object Oriented languages. In COMP 2011, you are supposed to have a solid understanding of Type, Function, and Struct. In Comp 2012, you will learn the rest of them.

Some syntax
int array[5];
int const* const* p = new int*;
int (*arrPtr) [5] = &array;
int (&arrRef) [5] = array;
int* (&ptrsRef) [10] = ptrs;
int (*fptr) (int, double) = function;
int (*const fpArr[]) (int, int) = {f1, f2, f3};
int (*fptr) (int) = [] (int x) -> int {};
int (* func(int))[10];
reviews.comment_teaching: Suppose you are interested in the CPP language itself. Then, I strongly recommend the book "C++ Primer," which elaborates on more features and detailed explanations. After this book, Effective CPP by Scott Meyers should be your best choice, which gives you suggestions on how to write clear and compelling codes. Finally, if I remember correctly, there is also an exprimental course in UST for those interested in Compiler, Comp 4901N Principles of Programming Languages. Sadly I haven't taken this course yet. So I don't know the details.
reviews.comment_grading:
19/21 Labs
100/100 Ass1
98/100 Ass2
100/100 Ass3
82.5/100 Mid
80/100 final
88/100 Overall
Final Grade A

I have a friend who got 87 overall and was only A- in the final grading. If you want a good grade, full marks in assignments and labs are necessary.
reviews.comment_workload:
Labs were simple. If you find them difficult, review the Comp 2011 or read the website learncpp.com immediately.

Each assignment takes me about 6 hours to code and a few more hours to debug. Don't wait until the last minute. The grading system will be slow hours before the deadline.

Exams require you a lot of effort to practice. Unfortunately, I didn't have enough time for the past papers. Maybe that's why I had a bit low scores on exams.
